Data:
What to Check For

Verify that sensitive information is not logged.

Why

Log files are usually less protected and available to more users than sensitive data files. Including sensitive information in logs may lead to unauthorized information disclosure.

How to Check

Use the following steps to verify that sensitive information is not logged:

  1. Identify sensitive data. Make a list of types of sensitive information handled by your application. Some examples are:

    • System information
    • Filenames and paths
    • Passwords
    • Encryption keys
    • Cardholder data
    • Personal information

  2. Identify logging functionality. Examine the application architecture to identify logging facilities, such as the logging API and where audit trails are actually stored. Make a list of APIs used to log events, document how to use them, and where they store logs.

  3. Examine logging functionality. Examine the logging subsystem to verify that it does not record any of the types of sensitive data used by the application.

  4. Examine logs. View existing logs and verify that they do not include sensitive information.

How to Fix

Perform the following actions to prevent logging of sensitive information:

  1. Identify sensitive data. Make a list of types of sensitive information handled by your application. Some examples are:

    • System information
    • Filenames and paths
    • Passwords
    • Encryption keys
    • Cardholder data
    • Personal information

  2. Identify logging functionality. Examine the application architecture to identify logging facilities, such as the logging API and where audit trails are actually stored. Make a list of APIs used to log events, document how to use them, and where they store logs.

  3. Review logging code. Identify code that generates log entries. Search code for the APIs that generate log entries to find all code that generates log entries. Review this code to verify that it does not include sensitive information in log entries. If necessary, rewrite this code in a way that does not log sensitive data.

  4. Prevent logging of sensitive data. The most effective measure for avoiding logging sensitive information is prevention, which means making sure that sensitive information does not get logged whenever writing code that generates log entries.

  5. Review logging of errors. Error logs often store sensitive data when they shouldn't. Pay particular attention to code that generates error logs, both when writing this code and when reviewing it, to make sure that sensitive information is not included in error messages or log entries.
